original_text: AA 2024-T3 aluminium alloy is widely used for aerospace applications due to its high strength to weight ratio and high damage tolerance that result from copper and magnesium as the principal alloying elements and appropriate thermomechanical processing. The microstructure of the alloy is relatively complex and a number of compositionally-distinct phases have been identified [1]. Although possessing favourable mechanical properties, the alloy is relatively susceptible to corrosion and generally requires surface treatment in practical applications. The corrosion behaviour of the alloy is particularly affected by the presence of the intermetallic particles due to their differing potentials with respect to the alloy matrix [2–9]. Copper-containing second phase particles at the alloy surface are particularly detrimental to the corrosion resistance as they provide preferential cathodic sites [2,10]. One of the principle types of second phase particle that is important to the corrosion behaviour of the alloy is the S phase (Al2CuMg) particle [1,11]. Dealloying of S phase particles, which may account for ∼60% of the constituent particles in AA2024 alloys [11], is commonly observed when the alloy is exposed to an aggressive environment. The particles are considered as important initiation sites for severe localized corrosion in the alloy [11–22]. The dealloying of the S phase particles and the resulting enrichment of copper result in a decrease of the Volta potential with respect to the matrix and hence the dealloyed particles become active cathodic sites [23–25].
original_translation: La aleación de aluminio AA 2024-T3 es ampliamente utilizada en aplicaciones aeroespaciales debido a su alta relación resistencia-peso y alta tolerancia al daño que resultan de cobre y magnesio como elementos principales de aleación y un procesamiento termomecánico apropiado. La microestructura de la aleación es relativamente compleja y se han identificado varias fases distintas en composición [1]. Aunque posee propiedades mecánicas favorables, la aleación es relativamente susceptible a la corrosión y generalmente requiere tratamiento superficial en aplicaciones prácticas. El comportamiento de corrosión de la aleación se ve particularmente afectado por la presencia de las partículas intermetálicas debido a sus potenciales diferentes con respecto a la matriz de la aleación [2-9]. Las partículas de segunda fase que contienen cobre en la superficie de la aleación son particularmente perjudiciales para la resistencia a la corrosión, ya que proporcionan sitios catódicos preferenciales. Uno de los tipos principales de partículas de segunda fase que es importante para el comportamiento de corrosión de la aleación es la partícula de fase S (Al2CuMg) [1,11]. La desaleación de las partículas de fase S, que pueden representar aproximadamente el 60% de las partículas constituyentes en las aleaciones de AA2024 [11], se observa comúnmente cuando la aleación está expuesta a un ambiente agresivo. Las partículas son consideradas como sitios de iniciación importantes para la corrosión localizada severa en la aleación [11-22]. La desaleación de las partículas de fase S y el enriquecimiento resultante de cobre provocan una disminución del potencial de Volta con respecto a la matriz y, por lo tanto, las partículas desaleadas se convierten en sitios catódicos activos [23-25].

La microestructura de la aleación es relativamente compleja y se han identificado varias fases distintas en composición [1]. Aunque posee propiedades mecánicas favorables, la aleación es relativamente susceptible a la corrosión y generalmente requiere tratamiento superficial en aplicaciones prácticas. Output: El comportamiento de corrosión de la aleación se ve particularmente afectado por la presencia de las partículas intermetálicas debido a sus potenciales diferentes con respecto a la
matriz de la aleación
[2–9]. Las partículas de segunda fase que contienen cobre en la superficie de la aleación son particularmente perjudiciales para la resistencia a la corrosión, ya que proporcionan sitios catódicos preferenciales. Uno de los tipos principales de partículas de segunda fase que es importante para el comportamiento de corrosión de la aleación es la partícula de fase S (Al2CuMg) [1,11]. original_annotated_sentences: AA 2024-T3 aluminium alloy is widely used for aerospace applications due to its high strength to weight ratio and high damage tolerance that result from copper and magnesium as the principal alloying elements and appropriate thermomechanical processing.
The microstructure of the alloy is relatively complex and a number of compositionally-distinct phases have been identified [1].
Although possessing favourable mechanical properties, the alloy is relatively susceptible to corrosion and generally requires surface treatment in practical applications.
The corrosion behaviour of the alloy is particularly affected by the presence of the intermetallic particles due to their differing potentials with respect to the alloy matrix [2–9].

Copper-containing second phase particles at the alloy surface are particularly detrimental to the
corrosion resistance
as they provide preferential cathodic sites [2,10].
One of the principle types of second phase particle that is important to the corrosion behaviour of the alloy is the S phase (Al2CuMg) particle [1,11].
Dealloying of S phase particles, which may account for ∼60% of the constituent particles in AA2024 alloys [11], is commonly observed when the alloy is exposed to an aggressive environment.
The particles are considered as important initiation sites for severe localized corrosion in the alloy [11–22].

The dealloying of the S phase particles and the resulting enrichment of copper result in a decrease of the Volta potential with respect to the matrix and hence the dealloyed particles become active cathodic sites [23–25].

original_annotated_sentences: AA 2024-T3 aluminium alloy is widely used for aerospace applications due to its high strength to weight ratio and high damage tolerance that result from copper and magnesium as the principal alloying elements and appropriate thermomechanical processing.
The microstructure of the alloy is relatively complex and a number of compositionally-distinct phases have been identified [1].
Although possessing favourable mechanical properties, the alloy is relatively susceptible to corrosion and generally requires surface treatment in practical applications.
The corrosion behaviour of the alloy is particularly affected by the presence of the intermetallic particles due to their differing potentials with respect to the alloy matrix [2–9].
Copper-containing second phase particles at the alloy surface are particularly detrimental to the corrosion resistance as they provide preferential cathodic sites [2,10].

One of the principle types of
second phase particle
that is important to the corrosion behaviour of the alloy is the S phase (Al2CuMg) particle [1,11].
Dealloying of S phase particles, which may account for ∼60% of the constituent particles in AA2024 alloys [11], is commonly observed when the alloy is exposed to an aggressive environment.
The particles are considered as important initiation sites for severe localized corrosion in the alloy [11–22].

The dealloying of the S phase particles and the resulting enrichment of copper result in a decrease of the Volta potential with respect to the matrix and hence the dealloyed particles become active cathodic sites [23–25].

que es importante para el comportamiento de corrosión de la aleación es la partícula de fase S (Al2CuMg) [1,11].
